Crump and Danielle Navarro Last Compiled 2021-09-16 Preface First Draft (version 0.9 = August 7th, 2018) Last Compiled: 2021-09-16 0.1 Important notes This is a free textbook teaching introductory statistics for undergraduates in psychology. This textbook was adapted from a larger OER course package for teaching undergraduate statistics in psychology, of which all materials are free and copiable, with source code maintained in Github repositories. The main OSF project link is https://osf.io/3s68c/. All resources are released under a creative commons licence CC BY-SA 4.0. Click the link to read more about the license, or read more below in the license section. 0.1.1 Features 0.1.1.1 Infoboxes Ive used various infoboxes throughout the book. Much of the text was primarily written by Matthew J. C. Crump. Jeff contributed the YouTube videos peppered throughout the textbook. All of Jeffs statistics videos are available on his Youtube channel: Statistics Video playlist. Alla, Anjali, and Stephen wrote the lab manual exercises for SPSS, JAMOVI, and Excel. Matt Crump wrote the lab manual exercises for R. Matt Crump wrote a free and copiable course website, in R Markdown. The course website also contains slide decks for the lectures. Two of the chapters were adapted from Danielle Navarros wonderful (and bigger) free textbook, also licensed under the same creative commons license. The citation for that textbook is: Navarro, D. (2018). Learning statistics with R: A tutorial for psychology students and other beginners (version 0.6). In general, I thank the larger R community for all of the amazing tools they made, and for making those tools open, so that I could use them to make this thing. All of the source code for compiling the original book is available in the GitHub repository for this book: https://github.com/CrumpLab/statistics 0.2.1 Acknowledgments Thanks to the librarians at Brooklyn College of CUNY, especially Miriam Deutch, and Emily Fairey, for their support throughout the process. Feel free to use hypothesis with this textbook. We will read your comments. Use Hypothes.is, an amazing tool for annotating the web.
